reviewText: Coming off the heels of a tiny 2007 film not widely released until two years later (budget was 15,000 dollars, ended up making close to 200 million), this sequel suffers from what many filmmakers astonishingly decide to do when a taut little package turns out to be pure gold; make it bigger, and most of all, make it dumber.What was probably most shocking about the first movie is that the paranormal activity around Katie was inexplicable.  There was no apparent reason other than randomness, no apparent solution, no explanation, nothing at all.  It was just there, haunting HER and not her house, and tormenting her for the demonic lulz.The mystery of it all was probably one of the strongest parts of what would otherwise be a conventional horror film (shot unconventionally).  Few things sap the intrigue and suspense from a horror film more than seeing the main character talking to "ghost experts" or researching at the library, uncovering everything about the supernatural whatever.  The Ring was great and all, but I find it hard to take a ghosty girl seriously when she died in the 1980s in a conventional way, and just didn't like horses because they were noisy.  It gets particularly annoying when mystery films or shows neatly wrap everything up with full-fledged explanations for every little clue, detail, motive, etcetera.  Part of the reason I love Law and Order (original) and dislike Law and Order Criminal Intent is that the vast majority of the time (in original) you NEVER KNOW FOR CERTAIN if the person on trial really did the crime.  You are left in the same position as real life; something bad happened, and someone got punished (or escaped punishment) based on the decision of 12 random people.Instead, this film would rather treat the audience as dumb, and have every facet of the film series in general explained and actions taken made very explicitly clear even early on in the film.  It made for a very disappointing film experience.First thing's first; it's scary, like the first film.  In my opinion, though, they reached too far, and the terror factor was diminished by the "embiggening" of the paranormal activity.  Things randomly moving on their own, doors creaking slightly, footsteps and noises occurring, sheets fluttering as if someone invisible were sliding into bed with you, people seemingly posessed and standing in place for hours on end, these were frightening, and present in both films.  This one adds more "stuff", more things moving around, more blatant "presences", more expensive set-pieces (like every drawer and cabinet in the kitchen bursting open at once).It wasn't too big of a deal, not nearly enough to use "less is more" as a complaint.  Instead, I use it as a complaint with regards to story.In the first movie, we meet Katie and Micah, a young couple with a camera, who start talking about ghosts and hauntings very early into the film.  The camera is set up to try and catch some of this activity, though it's not explained why until later.  The details unraveled are essentially: It's not a ghost, it's a demon, and it's not stuck to the house, but is after Katie herself, and will follow her no matter where she lives.How, why, nothing else is answered.  Nothing else is explained beyond this.  The demon has a partly-burnt photo of Katie as a little girl that it leaves in the attic to spook them.  How, why, nothing is answered.  The only apparent link was with some woman who experienced nearly identical hauntings decades earlier until she died.  Anything else related to that is not explained.In this film, it is established that the new girl, Kristi, is Katie's sister, and the events here are taking place 2 months before the events of the first film.  Same MO, slightly different spook-tactics, this time with a new factor; a baby boy.Close to the middle, but somewhat before that, in the movie, you're pretty much informed outright that the demon is after the baby, Hunter, despite what daughter Ali's boyfriend would deduce after tricking her with the ouija board (pussyhunt).  After a long period of spooky-haunting stuff, the real appeal of this movie, they begin tying it in to the first movie by providing explanation as to why the demon is haunting her, and providing a pathetically flimsy out that mirrors that of The Ring 2---turns out Kristi's demonic haunting is passed on to Katie, as depicted in the first film.Then adding the "sequel" bit to the "sequel-prequel" billing, Katie appears in their home, presumably moments after the events of the first film.  What transpires is pretty much pointless and no longer scary.But it's a franchise now.  I say that these expository events that excise all the mystery and terror of the unknown would have enhanced the movie... and yet I realize, without these things, the movie would essentially be a remake of the first.  It would've been great in hindsight if all these connections with the first movie were left unspoken, but even I don't think I would be able to put it together without the exposition.So basically, the explanations and the mystery-killing nature of it is essential for this film to even exist without being derided as a pointless cash-grabby remake.  It ruins the first film a bit (for me at least) but it gives THIS film its purpose.  It could still arguably be called a pointless cash-grabby remake, but it would at least fit in to the franchise as it stands now.  It's still interesting, but it's no longer scary.

reviewText: Paranormal Activity 2 is the sequel with really no improvements whatsoever.  However because I love the series, I can't help but give it a perfect 5-star rating anyway.  I honestly, truly believe anyone who's a fan of the Amityville Horror (the original one) will LOVE the Paranormal Activity series.  Alright, so Paranormal Activity doesn't necessarily wrap a storyline around these paranormal events, but then again, it's not really supposed to-  it's all about building horror and finding the creepiest ways imaginable to get underneath the sensitive side of the viewers.So why isn't the sequel better than the first one?  Well a couple reasons.  Now we have children.  Two children- one a teenage girl; the other a baby who spends most of his time in a crib.  We also have a German Shepherd always on alert.  PLUS the parents and the wifes sister.  Yes, with all these people involved, you can't possibly have a movie deliver with the suspense in the same way as the first one.  The simplicity of the setting and including only two people (a young couple) makes the first one much scarier.Also, another reason it's not as scary- the camera angles.  Whereas on the first Paranormal Activity the camera is mainly locked into one specific spot in the bedroom where the man and woman sleep, now the camera has a few other permanent positions, such as the baby's room above the crib, the living room/kitchen area, the swimming pool outback, and the hallway near the front door.  This means whenever the tension is about to build, the cameras alternate between all four of these areas.  I prefer the way it was done in the original.  That way we'd learn to appreciate and grow accustomed to the setting and the frightening scenes as our eyes absorbed into the darkness of the bedroom waiting anxiously for the next horrific scene.  With a camera switching between four different areas of the house, now there's not as much build-up in the suspense.On a similar note, it's amazing how brilliant the horror aspect works in a movie like this.  It's so simple and yet, a genius idea!  You learn to understand how the camera system works- when everything gets quiet and we return to a familiar camera position, you *know* something scary is about to happen, but there's never any telling what the actual scary moment will BE.  It could be anything!  There's literally hundreds of ideas the movie writers could have implemented.  I love it!Actually a third reason this isn't as scary as the first one is because now we know what to expect.  Honestly the movie writers should have kept this in mind because the first 3 or 4 paranormal scenes are VERY predictable and remarkably tame in comparison to even the mildest ones from the first Paranormal Activity film.  I don't want to spoil what they actually are in case you haven't seen them yet, so just know the BIG shocks won't appear until later.  Oh well- at least the movie doesn't take a while to get going this time around- you only have to wait 15 minutes until something unusual happens, whereas in the first one you had to wait 30 minutes.Now onto the positives-I have both Paranormal Activity 1 and 2 on DVD, and part two has *drastically* louder and better sound overall.  Honestly the first one is quite mild in the sound category, so you have to make constant adjustments on your volume button.  With part one, I recommend just turning it up louder than you normally would and leave it be.  With part two... you should probably turn the volume down a few notches.  With naturally louder volume, when the unexpected horror segments arrive, get ready to be REALLY scared!  I mean downright shocked!  I love it!Overall however, the amount of terrifying segments just aren't as numerous as in the first film.  Plus it seems like, with the parents, there's a "been there, done that" feeling for those of us who've watched the first Paranormal Activity movie (especially with the wife and how the evil lurking in the house takes over her mind and body).I'm not particularly fond of the setting- San Diego once AGAIN!  Let me share the same sentiments again (in case you haven't seen my review for the first Paranormal Activity that I submitted a couple weeks ago).  San Diego is the wrong location for a horror setting.  It's too mild there.  A much better place would be the northeast, especially anywhere from Massachusetts down to Georgia.Overall, expect a fantastic horror movie, but don't be surprised if it doesn't live up to your expectations, and definitely don't be surprised if it doesn't live up to the superior part one.
summary: awesome, but the first one is better

reviewText: I initially didn't like the first movie but the subtle eeriness of it slowly sank into my subconscious, freaking me out for weeks afterwards. It was pretty much a good understated horror movie which is a rarity with all of the "in your face" horror flicks that abound nowadays. Then they made this sequel.Think about everything in the first movie that you liked, repeat that formula but heavily diluted. Where the first movie managed to sink into your head with its slow buildup, this movie flounders in an attempt to copy itself. Instead of lulling you into complacency, only to shock you with some new demonic activity, this movie just fell flat on its face. When the big finale does occur it lacks the punch that its predecessor had.There's no tension, no real buildup here. The basic storyline is a good idea but it would have been better served if it'd been condensed and shortened. The filler is what really destroys the tension in this movie.In case you're thinking that I'm not the target audience (fair enough), I saw this with one of my best friends. She loved the first movie. It scared her so badly that she slept with the lights on even with her fiancee sleeping in the same room with her. She was bored to tears by this movie and almost fell asleep several times.I'll still give PA3 a try, but the shine is officially off this series. Unless the filmmakers bring something new to the table instead of rehashing the same idea over & over again, I honestly think this series has jumped the shark.

reviewText: If we don't find ourselves as scared as we did a year ago, it's because, this time around, we know exactly what to expect. There will be phantom thuds. There will be objects that move on their own. There will be doors that slam without the aid of a living person or a sudden gust of wind. In "Paranormal Activity 2," many of these phenomena are preceded by the sound of a low-frequency rumble, which essentially gives audiences a signal to prepare themselves, reducing the fright factor even further. All we have left are unoriginal shock tactics like sudden loud noises, bursts of poltergeist activity, and near the end, the now overused Queasy Cam. Sitting in the theater, I was disappointed. After leaving, it all made perfect sense; the first film worked so well that there was absolutely nothing anyone could have done to top it.Having said that, it's a shame no one made more of an effort to keep it on equal terms. "Paranormal Activity" was a relentlessly frightening movie, largely because it didn't assault the audience with conventional pop out scares. It was slow and steady unfolding of disturbing subtleties, like a time-lapse shot of Katie Featherston standing over her sleeping boyfriend and staring at him for hours and hours. It made no real effort to explain the situation. I'd be hard pressed to say that there was even a plot - it was all just sort of ... happening. Not only does "Paranormal Activity 2" have a discernable plot, it also provides an explanation for just about everything. This time around, there was no need to have it consist entirely of footage from surveillance cameras and camcorders; it could have been filmed and released as a standard supernatural thriller, complete with special effects, music, and sets.With the exception of the final scene, the film is actually a prequel, taking place in the months prior to the events of "Paranormal Activity." The focus is Katie's sister, Kristi (Sprague Grayden), who lives in Carlsbad with her husband, Dan (Brian Boland), her infant son, Hunter (William and Jackson Prietro), her teenage stepdaughter, Ali (Molly Ephraim), and the family dog. One day, they come home and discover that the house has been ransacked, although nothing was actually taken; fearing for their safety, Dan has six security cameras installed all throughout the house. Thus begins ... well, I think you know very well what begins. Many of the first film's unsettling touches are recreated, only this time, they're repeated to the point of monotony. Consider, for example, the persistent use of swimming pool footage; almost every sequence taking place in the middle of the night begins with a shot of the pool. It's an obvious attempt to get us to notice the automated cleaner, which gets out of the water seemingly on its own.Would it surprise you to learn that both the dog and the toddler are more intuitive than anyone else in the house? If this long dead cliché doesn't bother you, then perhaps the Hispanic maid will. Never mind the fact that communication is possible in spite of the fact that she can only speak Spanish while her employers can only speak English; she's devoutly religious and seems to sense that something evil is in the house. At one point, she lights incense and walks through the kitchen while chanting something in low, terrified murmurs. Despite the best of intentions, she can't get anyone in the house to heed her warnings - and let me reiterate that she only speaks Spanish. The audience I sat with found this character funny for some reason. Have we come to the point where comedy relief in horror movies is defined solely by ethnicity?The ending is immensely unsatisfying. Partly, it's because of an unpleasant decision made by certain characters, one that made me dislike them. Mostly, however, it was because the story actually resolved itself, and did so quite unoriginally. Watching it unfold, I began thinking about the conclusion of the previous film, which, at the time, I found absolutely horrifying; had I known it would be the catalyst for this prequel, I would have lobbied for writer/director Oren Peli to reinsert one of his two alternate endings, which, by their descriptions alone, are indisputably frightening.When "Paranormal Activity" was first released, many agreed that it was one of the scariest films they had ever seen. I seriously doubt people will say the same thing about "Paranormal Activity 2." Oh, it will certainly make you jump at times, but the slow, consistent, creeping terror of the original film is nowhere to be found. Was there any way this movie could have been better, or at the very least, just as good? I admit that I was excited when I first saw the trailer, but in all likelihood, that was just a fanboy reaction. I understand now - the bar was set too high, meaning there was nowhere for it to go other than down. This, of course, begs the question of why filmmakers push for sequels and/or prequels when it's clear that one film is all it takes. I live in hope that horror movies will someday be judged by their ability to scare people, not by their potential as the start of a franchise.
summary: A Prequel That Won't Cause Sleepless Nights

It's not a complete disaster; the way its story dovetails with the plot of the first is quite clever.  Unfortunately, this one is too much foreplay without enough payoff.  It also stretches credibility too much at times in order to put certain events on screen; I don't think a teenage girl would talk into a camera the way this one does, and most families would get a flashlight when the lights go out rather than rely on the light on their video equipment.  I also rolled my eyes at the stereotype of the Hispanic maid who just happens to be a fount of knowledge on demons and exorcism.

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I enjoyed the original Paranormal Activity (PA1) and I enjoyed this film as well.  If you didn't like the first film, I'm not sure why you would like this film, but conversely, if you enjoyed the original, you'll probably enjoy this one as well. reviewText: While I'm a fan of the horror genre -- enjoying the collective works of George Romero, Takashi Miike, and Rob Zombie's House of a Thousand Corpses and The Devil's Rejects -- I have to say that I'm a bigger fan of that sub-genre known as the psychological thriller. 2009's Paranormal Activity was one of the best examples of this genre that I had seen in quite a while, as its not-quite-documentary quality/low budget look gave the scares in this film an air of reality not present in most modern horror movies. However, given Paramount's initial intentions with Paranormal Activity and the fact that the studio commissioned a sequel before the first movie's run in theaters was over, I have to say that I wasn't too excited at the prospect of seeing a sequel merely a year after the release of its predecessor.Paranormal Activity 2 takes place about two months before the beginning of Paranormal Activity. A year after bringing newborn son Hunter home, Kristi (sister of the first film's Katie) and family experience a break-in, prompting them to install security cameras all over the house. As increasingly bizarre events continue to occur around the house, Kristi's stepdaughter Ali grows curious about what's happening, while Kristi looks back to similar instances that occurred during her and Katie's childhood.In their attempts to profit from the success of the original film, Paramount created a sequel that is close in spirit to the first PA. The resulting film was made for $3 million and still features a completely unknown cast, with the exception of the original leads. Still relying largely on POV cameras, this films also features security camera footage, a brilliant way to feature what's going on in all areas of the house. Seeing exactly what's going on in an unoccupied room, or even outside the house, builds on the suspense the audience feels as we wonder what's going to happen when the family members find themselves in the same room as a spirit entity.Also adding to the eeriness of this film is the presence of innocent players. Watching Hunter, Kristi's one-year-old son, creates a feeling of dread in the audience as we constantly worry about if and when something is going to happen to him. Hunter's presence also creates a greater feeling of empathy toward the family as they struggle to keep him safe. Another innocent player in this thriller is the family's German Shepherd, Abby, who for most of the movie is merely trying to protect Hunter from a perceived threat, and is included in one of the movie's scarier moments. The family dynamic is also more developed in this sequel than in the original film, as there are more players, each with an individualized stance on what exactly is going on in the house.For a movie that was sped into production, the plotting and attention to detail in Paranormal Activity 2 are brilliant. This film acts as both a prequel and sequel, and when you see how the pieces fit together it feels perfectly logical without feeling forced. Fans of the first film will recognize a few references to the original Paranormal Activity that work to further the plot not only of this movie, but the original as well.  The care taken with this plot shows that Paramount and the writers/director chosen to further the PA franchise respected the source material.While the broad plot of Paranormal Activity 2 offers brilliance, some elements of the smaller plot points seem unrealistic and fail to further the plot on a lesser scale. While adding the security camera footage greatly enhances the film, the initial break-in that created a need for the cameras is somehow immediately forgotten by the characters. Logically speaking, it seems that the presence of security cameras would most likely result in a cautious optimism rather than this complete amnesia regarding the initial incident. Also, Ali's research into what's going on the house is presented too late and expounds on the events too quickly. These elements made me miss the more realistic approach of the first movie, in which the characters consult an actual demonologist about the spirit invading their home rather than the internet.I found myself spending more time acquainted with the edge of my seat in this film than I did the first. On at least one occasion I nearly threw my popcorn all over myself, and I've only jumped out of my seat for two other movies that I've seen in theaters. I highly recommend this film. If you're a fan of the original, interested in anything dealing with demonology, or love psychological thrillers, chances are you're going to love this movie!

reviewText: I saw PA2 in the theater and was surprised how good it was -- an uncommonly effective sequel/prequel to the first PA film, which was a surprise in itself.What sets both films apart from so many so-called horror films today is the old-school less-is-more approach, perhaps necessitated on the first film by the shoe-string budget.Sound effects count for as much as visual effects, and there is barely a drop of blood to be seen anywhere.Instead, both films build suspense and terror the old-fashioned way -- slowly.  If you go back and watch the great horror films in cinema, you will see how carefully the terror is modulated.  The first big scares in "Alien" or "Psycho," to name just two classics, don't appear until at least thirty minutes into the film.At that point, you're fully invested in the characters and the situation and wondering what will come next.The two PA films also rely on the static video cameras monitoring much of the paranormal activity.  This technique forces viewers to pay close attention to the screen, to see the scares, which start small and gradually ramp up.  When you hear a low-frequency rumble on the soundtrack, it's demon time... Stop shoveling popcorn in your mouth and pay closer attention!I have deducted a star for the lack of extras on the DVD.  There is an extended version of the film -- which I watched, but couldn't distinguish from the version I saw in the theater.  There are also a few extra "found scenes", one of which is genuinely scary and worth seeing. reviewText: DISCLAIMER:  I loved, loved, loved Paranormal Activity.  If you didn't, then don't watch this.  This was made for people who liked the original.  The people involved in making this flick saw no need to modify that which a lot of folks already liked.  So here we go...In any movie where we, the audience, will watch a group of people under emotional duress it is the screenwriter and director's job to have us identify with them somehow; humanize them.  So let's meet the players.  This family has QUITE a house (much like the pleasantly affluent couple in Paranormal Activity).  The man of the house has not one but two--TWO--man caves!!!!  The first-born daughter is a hand full.  I was looking forward to the lines that would pour out of that sassy mouth.  How does such a child get raised?  Well, that double-man-caving husband coupled with a wife who clearly never plans on doing a diaper.  And why bother?  She has a Latin nanny to whom she may delegate at will.  The nanny tends to the baby, their infant son, who dad thinks will favor father-son Chargers games over video games as he enters adolescence.  Good luck with that bonding, dad!  Relating with this American portrait yet?This family is living the American dream.  A McMansion of a house, a nanny, an adorable baby, sunny California BBQ's by the pool, and a dog that doesn't seem to bark, bite, drool or hump anything.  I don't want it to end.  The father even quotes Highlander while dunking his nephew in the pool.  "There can be only ONE!"  Perfect.  A little too perfect?BAM!  The house is dilapidated!  It looks like they owed a hurricane money and it took it out on their interior decorating.  Without being any less intriguing for it, we find ourselves playing the exact same game as I did during the first Paranormal Activity.  We listen for strange noises.  We focus our eyes on random objects trying to convince ourselves whether or not they're moving ever so slightly.  When the dog stirs, stares or barks, we try to see what the dog is focusing on.  We get involved and otherwise meaningless security-cam footage of an uneventful house becomes a suspenseful ocular-sleuthing marathon.  Kudos to the filmmakers for taking me on this journey.  The movie develops from that point on and, well, you should know the kinds of things that follow.Completely off-topic, but the Latin maid speaks very little English, however she talks quite a bit.  No subtitles are offered to the audience when she speaks Spanish (to herself, in panic, in prayer, etc.).  But if you understand what she's saying, the movie is actually even more interesting.  Even more interesting than if they gave subtitles...because you know that you caught something that wasn't meant for everyone in the audience.  As I found myself understanding it I stopped to wonder how monolingual Americans would react to these indecipherable mutterings--would the mood be different?  No subtitles was a brilliant call.  Also, adding not only a dog OR a baby, but both, was a great call.  You'll find that you watch the baby much in the same way that you watch the dog.  They're both like windchime-harbingers of strange goings-on.I really enjoyed watching this movie.  There were times when I was watching the screen SOOOO carefully with my eyes darting about at details like a devout Ghost Hunter.  This movie was admittedly very similar to the prequel, but it was not a blatant repetition.  This sequel, unlike the original, also had a distinct protagonist: the daughter.
summary: Lots of tension, staring, ocular-sleuthing, listening and concentrating.  An awesomely different horror experience!

reviewText: When Paranormal Activity came out I didn't buy the hype.  But when I finally did see it in theaters, it really did spook me.  What's surprising is how little "gotcha" moments there are in the film - the horror is in the viewer's head, the dread rising to unbearable levels as we wait for the screaming release.Paranormal Activity 2 (PA2) takes this bait-and-hook filmmaking style to a new level. Kristi (Sprague Grayden) and Dan Rey (Brian Boland) live in a posh California home, complete with stepdaughter Ali (Molly Ephraim), Abby the German Shepherd, and adorable son Hunter.  After a paranormal entity trashes the house the movie shifts to security footage of the interior and the exterior of the house. But it's what the cameras don't show that nags at you: a dog barking at something off camera, a child staring upwards at the ceiling, an open basement door.No PA film would be complete without the unbelieving idiot, and Dan takes the role of Micah from the first film.  When housekeeper and nanny Martine (Vivis Cortez) tries to cleanse the house of evil by "smudging," Dan fires her.  It's only later that we realize this film takes place in the same universe as the first, when Kristi's doomed sister Katie (Katie Featherston) and Micah (Micah Sloat) appear in the film.Then your brain really begins to spin.  Since the events in the second film take place before the first, why are there no references to what happened in PA? Why are Kristi and Katie experiencing similar hauntings? And what the heck does the entity want with Hunter?Like the first film, Paranormal Activity revels in the things we fear most.  The horror is in the darkest part of the house (the attic in the first film, the basement in the second).  PA2 revolves around Hunter, the first boy born in generations to the family, which becomes a major plot point.  If this was just another haunting like the first installment, PA2 would be rather mundane, but fortunately it's much more than that - it is both a prequel and a sequel to the original, adding more material to the mythology that started the series.Character-wise, this film is weaker than the first .The father is irritatingly stubborn about his family's circumstances, and at times different characters disappear for stretches of time without explanation - Ali gets locked out of the house for over a half hour while the baby is inside sleeping but neither calls the police nor breaks a window; the housekeeper exits, enters, and mysteriously exits the plot; and Dan's sudden conversion to the supernatural beggars belief.  PA2's backstory detracts somewhat from the horror of the first movie, because it gives the paranormal a more coherent motivation. But then, this wouldn't be much of a franchise if it had nothing in common with the first installment.PA2 is most frightening for new parents.  Knowing that a child is at risk heightens parents' anxiety, literally demonizing our fear of child abductions.  But if you really want to be frightened, watch this film at home at night during a storm.  When the cable went out and our house alarm went off...let's just say it added to the suspense. We weren't able to finish watching the last fifteen minutes of the film until Halloween.

reviewText: Like many others out there, I loved watching the first `Paranormal Activity', because it was one of the few movies that year that actually scared me, and made me lose sleep for a few nights after viewing it. So I knew I had to go see `Paranormal Activity 2', and this is my review on it.Synopsis: The Rey family has just moved into their new home. The family consists of Dan (the father), his wife Kristi (who is also the sister of Katie from movie 1), their baby boy Hunter, and Ali, Dan's teenage daughter from his first marriage. As soon as they move in, one day they notice the furniture in most of the rooms wrecked, except Hunter's room, but nothing is stolen as such. They assume it was probably a break-in, and install security cameras around the house to catch anyone trying to break in again.As the days pass, strange incidents that occurring in the house that no one can explain. Dan doesn't witness any of the paranormal activity as such, and therefore refuses to believe that there is something supernatural happening in the house. Kristi starts experiencing some activities, but Katie tells her not to react on it, or it would just get worse. The only person who really starts taking the activities seriously is Ali, because initially she thinks that her mother is trying to reach her, but after researching further, she figures out what the root cause of the paranormal activities are. Can the Rey family survive whatever's inhibiting the house before its too late?NOTE: My review below contains quite a few spoilers, so if you haven't seen the movie and don't want to know what is going to happen, please skip ahead and read the last paragraph.Review: Although many people consider Paranormal Activity 2 to be one of those movies that you either love it or hate it, I actually had mixed feelings with this movie. While I liked it for the most part, I felt that there were some aspects to the story that made me slightly disappointed with it.What I liked: I loved how the story takes place in the timeline that coincides with the first movie, as this answered a lot of my questions as to what happens in the first movie as well. We get to see why Kristi starts experiencing the paranormal activities, and how this in turn affects Katie in the first movie as well. Most of the horror movies sequels that I have watched either take place before or after the first movie's timeline, so I really enjoyed how `Paranormal Activity 2' timeline stars off before the first movie and gradually catches up to it and goes beyond it.I also enjoyed the fact that the story was paced really well, and staying true to the first movie, we see the activities starting to occur gradually in the house. The cast also did a great job in their performances, and it was great to see Katie and Micah make appearances in this one as well. The house itself looked really lavish, and I also liked the idea viewing the occurrences through security cameras around the house.What disappointed me (spoiler alert): While the movie had some really terrifying moments to it (like the cupboards all opening at once), I think the major part of the story that ruined my experience was towards the end. I still don't want to give away the scene for those who didn't see the movie yet, but there is a scene where the entire family goes to the basement to basically get rid of the demon. While I can understand that this is one of the main parts that links this movie to its predecessor, it just seemed really unrealistic that Dan, who never believed in any of these things till moments before the end, could suddenly (with the help of Martine the maid) perform an exorcism so easily in around 10 minutes to get the demon transferred to another body. I'm sorry, but this seemed like a lame way to link the two movies together, and it felt that the writers got lazy towards the end and just came up with this idea in the last minute. I would have enjoyed the story better, if say they brought in the psychiatrist (from the first movie who comes to Katie's house regularly), or someone from the church etc. to remove the demon from Kristi. The main idea of the father doing this in the end, and his family still living in the same house after that, and not to mention that we never find out what happened to the maid after that incident etc. just seemed a little ludicrous to me.Also, because a lot of questions are answered in this movie as to why the paranormal presence is targeting the family (and also Katie's family), this movie didn't have that eerie effect on me like the first movie did, because the first movie had a lot of questions that were unanswered (like why the presence wouldn't let go of Katie), so it left a lot of theories open for interpretation, and I enjoyed this aspect about it. Whereas, in this movie, we find out why everything is happening, so there's no room for interpretation. We just get to see how the family tackles the demon, and while I enjoyed this, it didn't scare me in anyway or make me lose any sleep over it like how the first one did.Overall, I think if the explanations for the incidents in the story were explained in a better manner, I would have loved this movie, and even considered it better than the first movie. However, because of my problems with the scene mentioned above, `Paranormal Activity 2' still remains a good sequel, but not as good as the first movie.
summary: Good sequel, but not as good as its predecessor

reviewText: Last year, the horror phenomenon Paranormal Activity was released. The film was probably one of the most polarizing films of the year: Some thought it was scary as hell, others thought it was boring and like home videos. I, personally, side with the "scary as hell" side and loved it enough to file it under my "Best Movies of 2009" list. It reminded me of WHY we watch horror films: to feel fear and dread, to be scared and not watch people get killed in gory ways or having crap jump out at you. There were a few jumps but the film was tension fueled, which made it brilliant.Now a year later, and a sequel is released. And thankfully, it manages to be just as great, and maybe even more terrifying!!! I swear with these movies, the horror genre has some hope left. In a world of crap like My Soul To Take (I didn't want to waste a long amount of time ranting so I wrote a review of MSTT in poem format), jump fueled PG-13 horror and gore/torture porn, for once we're getting horror movies that are not only ACTUALLY scary, but follow the rule that Hitchcock set up when he was making movies: the scariest aspect is what we don't see.This film takes place 62 days before Micah Sloat died. A new family is the focus, and the mother, Kristy, is Katie's sister. They seem happy, as they have a beautiful daugher Ali, and a CUTE baby boy Hunter. The family has been experiencing a series of what could be called break-ins. We see ONE aftermath of them- and the house looks like a tornado blew through it- broken beer bottles, stuff broken, things scattered everywhere, etc. The family then resorts to hiring a surveillance team to install a series of cameras around the house, in case any suspicious activity happens.However, these clearly are no break-ins. Martin, the Spanish maid, has a spooky experience one night when a giant thump reverberates through the kitchen. Things get even spookier when Ali gets locked out of the house, and some even creepier stuff happens too, one involving the baby. And then, from there... things go from creepy to downright TERRIFYING. The same demon that haunted Micah Sloat and Katie Featherston is haunting them. But DOUBLE as scary, and to the point where you can't take the scariness anymore.I was worried this film would not live up to its predecessor, but thank God that worry proved useless. I loved it just as much as Paranormal Activity the first one. Sure the scares are recycled, but they did that for a reason- the same demon is haunting them. That means the household the demon haunted is off to do his tricks to the next household, which, if you ask me, makes it all the more scary to think about. Like the first, this one follows the Hitchock rule. But from the "Kitchen" scene, the terror level increases. the film thereon becomes disturbing as hell and just downright terrifying.Another thing I must praise is that this movie manages to bring a new element to the series- the feeling of being alone, and experiencing a terrifying moment not just at night but at all times of the day. The "kitchen" scene is a good example of this- in fact that scene alone made the movie more effective than the first. Ever had those moments where you have been alone in your home, and somehow knew you weren't alone? That an unseen presence is with you? That something can happen at any time? This movie focuses on that in the same fashion the first movie focused on what happens when you sleep.In short, Paranormal 2 is a success, and proof there is still hope for the horror genre. If you liked this one, give it a chance, and even if you didn't like the first, still give it your best shot. I certainly loved it as much as the first, and it also must be seen on the big screen- whereas the first worked better at home, this must be seen at the theatre with a packed crowd like I saw it tonight. Recommended for sure, and be prepared to be scared out of your mind!!!
summary: ...and you thought strange stuff happened ONLY when you sleep!

reviewText: PARANORMAL ACTIVITY was flat-out one of the scarier movies of recent years.  The simple story, told with the low-budget device of all the events being captured on a home camcorder, was remarkably effective and the film gave a sensation of reality and was extremely creepy.  Most "scary" movies just go for giving you a jump-in-your-seat moment...if t hey can momentarily make your heart beat faster, that's success enough.  PARANORMAL actually made me feel a little bit anxious, even after the film was over.Inevitably, PARANORMAL ACTIVITY 2 cannot be so successful, because it used many of the same conventions as the first.  The shock of newness has worn off.  That being said, it is a far, far better sequel than anyone had the right to hope for.We meet a family in Southern California on the day the couple comes back from the hospital with their new baby, Hunter.  Dad is a nearing middle-aged man with a teenage daughter, Ali, from a previous marriage.  His wife is considerably younger...but not to the point of being ridiculous.  They have a nice, older housekeeper and a German Shepherd.  They are a pretty happy group...the teen daughter is actually a nice, intelligent, helpful young lady.  There's no marital strife.  Life is good.One day, they experience a break-in, so Dad has a security system installed, with camera's focused on several spots of the house at once.  This device allows for several angles to be captured at one time...because their domestic bliss is soon interrupted by strange events.  This is how PA2 is a step forward from PA.  The first film relied exclusively on footage captured on one camcorder.  Now we have about 6 different shots of the house, along with camcorder footage.  It's a nifty (if obvious) device...but it's pretty important.  We can now watch mysterious things happening in more than one location at a time.  It becomes pretty clear early on that whatever paranormal activity is going on in this household is directed primarily at young Hunter.I do not want to give away any more plot, because there are actually some surprises in store.  And the first movie does have an unexpected connection to the sequel...a very clever and satisfying one, in my opinion.  In fact, I somewhat regret not watching the first one again prior to seeing the sequel.The movie retains, for the most part, the low-budget feel.  We're supposedly watching "found" footage again.  However, because several cameras were used, obviously significantly more editing was needed...therefore the movie feels just a little less "found" than before.  And the acting, frankly, is just a bit slicker than the first time.  This all results in a very low-budget movie that still feels ever so slightly glossy.  Probably not enough to detract from the overall experience...but I certainly noticed.The film, in my opinion, offers more creepiness and fewer genuine frights than the first.  It plays off our sense of dread very well.  For nearly 90 minutes, you sit there worried about what will happen next.  This doesn't really happen in horror films very often, and it is an uncomfortable yet pleasurable experience.I was very skeptical that PARANORMAL ACTIVITY 2 would be anything more than a cheap rip-off of the first...a pure cash grab.  I'm very happy to report that this is actually a highly-satisfying, unexpectedly clever sequel that tries, first and foremost, to creep you out.  If you liked or loved the first film, you'll enjoy this one as well.  If, for some reason, you disliked the first...stay away and let the rest of us enjoy!
summary: A surprisingly solid, and still creepy, sequel.

reviewText: Paranormal Activity 2 (Tod Williams, 2010)I started watching horror films in 1974, at the tender age of six, with The Exorcist. That one left with me with nothing but a raging crush on Linda Blair (that still burns thirty-six years later, by the by). And any other movie you can think of that got trumpeted "scariest movie EVAR!" by some critic or other pretty much left me the same way, either wanting to see it again because it's just awesome or wondering what all the fuss was about. In the intervening time, I've seen hundreds of horror movies. Maybe over a thousand. Of them, there have been four that, after the first seeing of them, I have absolutely refused to spend any time in a dark room. The first was Larry Hagman's 1972 Beware! The Blob, and in my defense, I was eight years old. (Can't remember completely, but I think it was the scene in the barbershop that traumatized me.) Second came Pet Sematary, my junior year in college (the sister did it, absolutely). The third was Candyman (it's the sound mix in the first meeting between Virginia Madsen and Tony Todd, which means if you haven't seen it on the big screen, you've no idea what I'm talking about). And the fourth, and I can't tell you what did it without insane amounts of spoilers, was Paranormal Activity 2.The worst part is, it's not all that good a movie, really. If we learned one thing from the original Paranormal Activity, a movie I was very impressed with, it's that Oren Peli is a master of blocking shots. If we learn one thing from Paranormal Activity 2, it's that Tod Williams (The Adventures of Sebastian Cole) does one hell of an Oren Peli impersonation. But every time he tries to revise and extend the convention of the original (and to be fair, he only does that once), he turns to the language of another film. (Or, to put that in not so kind a tone, the climax here is a complete rip-off of the climax of Jaume Balaguero's superior [REC].) I walked out of the theater thinking "meh" and figuring I'd give it three stars for being watchable and having a few really good jumps, but not being anything at all original. And then I got in the car and started home, and the impact of the movie started to creep in, and by the time I'd finished the seven- or eight-minute drive, I was gibbering and cowering in the corner and crying for my mommy like a schoolgirl. And that has not a blessed thing to do with Tod Williams, or almost anyone else involved in this picture; it has to do with a guy whose name you probably don't know, Michael Perry. But more on that in a minute.Plot: this is a prequel of sorts to the original Paranormal Activity, which allowed the team to bring back Katie and Micah, the beautiful couple from the first film. (Yes, guys, Katie Featherston is still that hot.) They are marginal characters, however. The film actually centers around Katie's sister Kristi (I should've jotted down names, because IMDB isn't listing anyone but Katie Featherston as I write this), her husband Dan, Kristi's stepdaughter Ali, and Dan and Kristi's son Hunter, who begins the film as a newborn, but is about a year old when the bulk of the action takes place. If you've seen the original, you know exactly how this is going to block out; you're going to be bored off your skull for the first half of the film with home movies. (To be fair, Williams does start the minor things happening pretty quick, but nothing that will make you jump until much later.) At one point, they come home and find the house trashed, so they have a security company come in and put up hidden cameras in the house. You know what's coming from there; you've seen the original, and Williams does nothing until the last ten minutes of the film to differentiate it from its older brother.Those last ten minutes are all down to Michael Perry, who's written for such disparate, but excellent, TV shows as House, Millennium, and FreakyLinks. He does just about everything that makes me hate a sequel if I know it coming in, but he somehow manages to do it all correctly. First and most importantly, he took a two-person film (and anyone who knows me will tell you I'm a sucker for a two-person film) and made it into a family gig. I figured that was strike one before I even walked into the theater, but I have a friend who has both a German Shepherd and a toddler who steadfastly refuses to see this movie because it contains a German Shepherd and a toddler. I admit, I was one of those poking fun at her, since she's as much a horror fan as I am. But Perry knows how to mash your buttons like a caffeinated twelve-year-old playing Super Mario World, and I totally get it now, even though I have never owned a German Shepherd and haven't had a toddler in well over a decade. You add a kid and you add an animal and while you're taking the easy road to scaring the bejesus out of your audience, you're taking the effective road.Second, there's the whole "there was no explanation for the bad stuff in the first movie" syndrome. Scary things are scarier, in general, when you have no freakin' clue why they're even happening. As a side note, it also avoids those messy plot holes. (Combine those two things and that's what makes Ils such a better movie than Haute Tension, for example.) I figured it was inevitable that Perry would do the "let's explain the events of both movies here!" thing, and so I wasn't surprised when he did. And it's not even all that original an explanation, but it's simple, it's effective, and it does explain both movies perfectly... especially when you get to those last ten minutes.Which brings me to point #3. It depends on which version of the original film you saw (I have seen two, and have been told at least one more exists) and how you interpreted the events in the final scene if you saw the correct (read: original) ending. If you thought you were seeing what I thought I was seeing (most of the action took place off-camera, as you'll recall), then I can't figure out a way that the last ten minutes of this movie don't break canon. I've been trying to make it work in my head ever since I saw the movie. I'll have to go back and re-watch the end of the first one tonight to see if I missed something, but as far as I can tell, there's a canon fracture here... and I didn't care, which astounds me more than anything else about this movie. It didn't. matter. one. bit. It's cheap and it's loose and it's so obviously tacked on for convenience's sake (like a number of other pieces of the script) and it doesn't matter because it's like getting hit smack in the forehead with a piledriver. And yes, when you're sitting in a brightly-lit cafe with your pals, you will deconstruct this ending and you will, rightly, tear it to shreds, as you will for most of the movie. But the fact that it's not well-conceived does not in any way mean it is not well-executed. While trying not to give anything away, I will risk a possible slight spoiler and say that the entire reason this ending works is the ambiguity of it. It's obvious that Perry knows exactly what he's doing by making this ending ambiguous. I think had he shown what happens in the conclusion to which you are obviously being led, it wouldn't have had nearly the effect that it did. Instead, he just lets it hang there and lets your imagination do the work. That's some sort of demented genius, though I'm not sure what yet.While unsuccessfully searching for cast information for this flick (and Katie Featherston fetishists take note that the actress who plays Kristi really could be her sister, just shorter hair and a bit perkier of a personality), I stumbled across a story where Peli is interviewed, along with Featherston and Sloat. In it, Sloat comments, "When you can't really see what's going on, your imagination starts to run wild. And the truth is that anything you can imagine is going to be better than anything you can actually see." That's it, exactly, it's why this works (and where it stumbles in certain places when Williams crosses the line between "showing just enough" and "maybe showing just a little bit too much and giving the game away"). Peli says "It taps into people's primal fears of what happens at night and while you're asleep and most vulnerable." And I have yet to see if my second night post-Paranormal Activity 2 will let me shut off a light.I have no idea how to rate this film. It's derivative, it's not especially well-made, it takes no risks, and the downside of putting more than two actors in a movie is that you run the risk of getting some who just aren't all that great at acting. But I cannot deny that, quite simply, this movie scared the living hell out of me more than any movie I've seen in the past eighteen years. It's base, it's manipulative, but it's brutally effective. As outright ludicrous as the comparison is, perhaps you should think of it as the thinking man's I Spit on Your Grave; it's just as manipulative and exploitative, but it relies on atmosphere instead of all those messy bits. So given how conflicted I am (and given how I want to get this out before the first showing on the east coast, which I think is in about an hour and a half as I write this), I'm going to give it the gentleman's C and let you decide. ***Oh, one other thing, and I can't believe I didn't say it it's so obvious: do not see this without seeing the first one. The final portion of the film will make basically no sense without it, and it contains THE major spoiler for Paranormal Activity. (See the first one with the original ending, if you can; I think the original ending may be on Youtube.)

reviewText: Thanks to "Scream 2," everybody knows the rules for horror sequels - more gore, more exotic death scenes, more T&A;, and a nasty tendency to explain more about the villain, thereby making the villain less scary.  Based on these rules, virtually no horror sequel holds a candle to the original that sparked the franchise.Fortunately, the team behind "Paranormal Activity 2" knows these rules well enough to avoid them.  "Paranormal Activity 2" does not truly dive deeper into the story of Micah and Katie, the doomed couple from "Paranormal Activity."  Instead, this sequel expands upon their story by telling a parallel tale about Katie's sister Kristi (Sprague Grayden), her husband Dan (Brian Boland), Dan's teenage daughter Ali (Molly Iphraim) and their baby son Hunter.  Kristi and Katie have remained close, and this sequel takes place largely in the weeks leading up to Katie's and Micah's tale of terror.Kristi and Dan are delighted to bring Hunter home to their SoCal not-quite-McMansion.  They barbeque with Katie and Micah and shoot loving home movies in their bucolic backyard swimming pool.  But soon their house is broken into, and strangely, nothing is taken.  This little development is nothing more than a cute contrivance to get the same security-cam video structure that made the first movie so spooky.[Mild Spoiler Alert]  The installation of the security cams gets things rolling, as we now get to see the creepily low-budget yet realistic security footage of spectral beasties doing that voodoo that they do so well.  Certain film critics may sneer at this movie as a collection of "gotcha" moments, but the movie skilfully builds tension from small moments of fright to genuine terror.  We learn a bit more about Katie's history with the demon from the first movie, but not so much as to rip all the fun out of this story.If you liked the first movie, you will definitely appreciate that this movie goes to great lengths to add to the first movie rather than merely ride its coattails.
summary: Terrific elaboration on the original "Paranormal Activity"

reviewText: Last year I saw "Paranormal Activity" on my birthday so I was all excited to do the same thing again this year. I saw "Paranormal Activity 2" yesterday again on my birthday, but I certainly am glad that I only paid college movie theater prices ($5). I'd have been really annoyed if I paid beaucoup bucks to see the sequel. "Paranormal Activity" was creepy and exciting and weird. This movie included the lady in the last movie with her sister, and it talked about the connection between the siblings and what was going on outside of her home. The difference with the sequel is that there was a baby, a German Shepherd, a married couple, a teenage girl, a babysitter/maid and the teenage girl's boyfriend involved.My initial thought was, "The first movie was so creepy because they had to depend on each other and there was no one to turn to." This movie seemed to have too many people, but when the babysitter/maid was kicked out and the boyfriend wasn't constantly around, I thought, "Okay, well, they're slowly filtering people out." The keyword here is "slowly." This movie was entirely too slow. I could've sworn I saw night #19 two times, but why on Earth did it take so long to get to the action? I'm almost positive it was a good 40 minutes into the movie before viewers saw anything remotely scary or even exciting. I got so tired of looking at that dumb pool and the countertop. Enough! I wanted to be scared, and this movie was not fulfilling my paranoia request.Another problem I had--that any dog owner should, especially a German Shepherd owner of which I've lived with two--was that the dog was so relaxed when noises were heard. The teenage girl and the wife would go running downstairs anytime they heard anything, but the dog would stay in place. It wasn't like they told the dog to "Stay." The dog just wasn't around. She was in the baby's room just sleeping like she had a sedative. Dogs don't operate like this. If I stand up to go wash my hands, both dogs I've lived with are almost knocking me in the hip to get to the sink first. Even the most well-trained dog, especially German Shepherds who are naturally inquisitive and incredibly protective, will hear the noises LONG before a human would and will investigate. By the time the dog started acting like a dog I was bored with its whole existence.This movie just didn't cut it. There are some films that don't need to be made into sequels, and this was one of them.

reviewText: Paranormal Activity 2 starts out as a prequel to the original movie (starting several months earlier) and then moves forward to where the latter parts of the film are concurrent with Paranormal Activity 1.  In the first movie the fact that Katie had a sister was mentioned briefly but she was never seen.  In this chapter, the sister, Kristi, and her family are the main characters.  Kristi, her husband, and the husband's teenage daughter from a previous marriage, are welcoming a new baby into the family when strange things start to occur.  The major incident is an apparant home invasion with the whole house trashed but nothing seemingly taken.  After this event, the family has a number of security cameras installed inside and outside the house, and the rest of the movie covers what is caught on these cameras.Inexplicable events continue happening, and the possibility of some supernatural prescence is increasingly raised by everyone except that the father of the family, who firmly thinks that's all nonsense.  Of course, the intensity of these otherworldly manifestaions continues increasing...Much more backstory is given as to why all this is occuring, and although the hinted origins of the haunting are powerful, on the other hand it takes away a bit of the mystique.  In the first Paranormal Activity, I thought one of the things that made it so powerful and eerie was that no reasons were ever floated for what was happening.  The prescence fixated on Katie and, as we learned from her relating of events from her childhood, had done so before.  But the movie never attempted to explain why, or go in deep as to exactly what the prescence was or what it wanted.  Every discovery made, such as the photograph that turned up in the attic, raised more questions than it answered.  And I think that really made it scarier, the viewer was a much in the dark as to all the "why"s as the characters, and it feels like there may not even be any "why", at least not that a human could understand.  Any motivation or origin behind the entity and the haunting are left not only to the best guesses of the characters, but to the viwer's interpretation.In Paranormal Activity 2, we get a much clearer picture as to why things are happening the way they are.  The explanations as to the origin of the hauntings is innovative and disturbing, but I almost think they should have left the origins here firmly in the 'unexplained' category, and they used the (admittedly cool) origin story in a whole different movie.  It looks like they're going to delve even further into the backstory in Paranormal Activity 3, and that could either go too far and rob the series of much of its mystique, or it could throw in some curveballs and restore that little portion that was kind of weakened.That possible weakening of the air of the unknown is the only weakness here, though.  The origin is frightening in its own right, and the whole movie is very well done, tremendously atmospheric and possessing some great jolts.  As with Part 1, there's a mix of scenes that unfold very slowly and creepily, where you really have to watch to see the supernatural elements taking hold, and much faster, more explosive scenes where the entity is gaining strength and things are coming to a head.  Great acting and characterization.  Overall, it may not be quite as great as the first one (on some levels) but it's still a 9/10.  Definately one every horror fan has to see for him- or herself.
summary: Powerful And Scary - Almost As Good As The First

reviewText: Sequels for horror films are normally and creatively the bottom of the barrel.  The formula for slasher and gore films was tiresome in 1982--and here we are decades later and the studios who had nothing to do with slasher films are making them!What I liked about PARANORMAL ACTIVITY was how footage was put together and the audience had to study over shot carefully.  When was the last time you paid that much attention to a security camera looking at an empty room?  And yet we were looking for something that wasn't really there...but it was.  And that's scary.So PARANORMAL ACTIVITY 2 wisely does the same thing AND develops a related story that includes the first film's characters.  I thought that was smart.  And it explained why the demonic presence was targeting Katie in the first film.So if you liked the first film, you'll probably like this one.  And if the filmmakers can keep their creative streak going, I'd even check out another sequel.

reviewText: I totally disagree with the Amazon reviewer, who of course has to praise the film lavishly so that people buy the DVD. The truth is, very little happens during the first 75 minutes of the film, and the final 15 minutes are disappointing.  The problem here is two-fold.  First, the repetition - night after night of nothing happening gets boring fast.  Secondly, there are hardly any scares in the film (pool cleaners exiting the pool are not scary; neither are falling pots, closing doors or crying babies) and what few scares there are rely on cheap loud noises to startle the audience. I didn't like the first film, but at least its scares were well-earned.  For example, there is nothing here as remotely creepy as PA1's images of the girl hovering over her boyfriend for hours or the paw prints in the baby powder.  To make matters worse, there are some ridiculous things about this film such as the family not moving out once they saw the footage of the mom being dragged by an invisible presence.  What??!!  Any sane person would have left the house immediately.  This should have been much better.  I'm not a movie director, but I'm confident that if I had the same budget to work with I could make a much scarier movie.

reviewText: If you didn't like the first Paranormal Activity I strongly doubt you will enjoy Paranormal Activity 2 so don't even bother, stay far away from it. I was one of those who liked Paranormal Activity and thought it was entertaining and somewhat different from other horror movies as well. The concept of all these paranormal events going on and purposely cheaply-made film was intriguing and best of all, it worked. The thing is there were parts were I was genuinely scared, I couldn't help but be a little freaked out by what the characters were going through. This second PA movie is actually the prequel to the first one and not a traditional sequel like you would imagine, it has elements of both a prequel and a sequel (that's the best way of putting it). It can be a little difficult to imagine a second film that wouldn't ruin what the first one did, be different and still have the effect the first had. I was curious enough and found this one just as enjoyable as the first one. Paranormal Activity 2 doesn't really cover new ground but with careful improvements and changes, works just as well if not better than the original. I respect that they obviously didn't want to ruin what the first movie did which tends to be hard for a sequel, they clearly cared enough and wanted to show viewers something worthy (and I'll say it was).Paranormal Activity 2 begins two months before the first film and what happens in this prequel leads to the first. This time around the story is focused on Dan, his wife Kristi, Dan's daughter Ali and son Hunter who are-you guessed it-victim of paranormal activity. It's becoming clear to viewers that something is after baby Hunter and will go through anything to get him, even family members. Dan is a skeptic and refuses to talk about these events until it comes to a point he can no longer ignore. His daughter Ali believes and researches the events happening to the family. This leads to a situation. Now, the story is nothing new but it soon all falls into pieces. If you believe or not in these things is not the point, you are likely to be captivated, guessing and wondering what's coming next. What's interesting is that you see Katie and Micah from the first PA and you even see them at their house and Micah with his Camera. I felt this one explained more of what happened in PA which only helps of course. For me, when watching the first film it took some time to really get into it but once you're in, it's quite a ride. PA 2 is no different but there are some elements that made it even more enjoyable for me. It starts out nice and easy, then gradually things begin to happen and it gets progressively worse, it's a formula that worked well for the first and it also applies here. In this one the acting is much better, there are cameras all over the house and the story behind it all was really interesting. The family dog, a German shepherd named Abby who also feels a presence in the house; animals usually feel those types of things before humans do and only contributes to make things more interesting. In the first PA, it seemed things only happened when the characters were asleep, which made sense. This time around things happen both during night and day which adds another dimension to PA.I was definitely freaked out after viewing, I kept thinking about what I've just seen on the screen. Paranormal Activity is deeply psychological that's why it's so interesting to some and won't appeal to others. It certainly makes one think about the paranormal and raise questions, but that's probably what the filmmakers want you to do. If you liked the first one chances are you will also like this one, I probably enjoyed this prequel/sequel more than the first. I feared this one might be bad but I must say that the experience is just as valid as in the first movie. Some things about PA 2 are very similar to the first, yet it's also different in its own way, after all no one experiences things in the same way. Just to make things clear, it's not "the scariest film ever!" or "the worst movie ever made" as some reviewers said. You may have seen the first movie but are you sure you're ready this time around? 4/5.

reviewText: "Paranormal Activity 2" is a prequel to the horror film released in 2009. The new chapter, which takes place several months before the events described in the first entry, revolves around Kristi Rey (Sprague Grayden), sister of the original's heroine Katie (Katie Featherston), and Kristi's family - Daniel (Brian Boland), his teenage daughter Ali (Molly Ephraim) and a baby named Hunter.The basic storyline is almost the same as the first installment. In a sense this is not surprising. Perhaps the producers thought (rightly) that they had to turn the previous year's surprise hit into a franchise quickly. So in "PA2" scares sometimes look recycled, using unexpected loud sound and moving objects. Despite the new characters (and a dog), sometimes I felt as if watching a remake, not a prequel, of the earlier film.The story of "Paranormal Activity 2" (especially its introductory part) unfolds at a faster speed. With footage ostensibly shot by the family's camcorder and several surveillance cameras installed in the house, the film tries to retain the same visual touch as the first one, but the tighter editing and more polished camerawork (and special effects) suggest a bigger budget and professional skills behind the supernatural phenomena.That is not bad thing. "Paranormal Activity 2" delivers what it promises to deliver. Only that novelty is gone.
summary: (2.5 STARS) Prequel That Looks More Like a Remake
